Description: Body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery thinnish-walled closed vessel; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of lower part of male figure to right, wearing long chiton with added red and added white rosettes and himation, and holding staff; naked leg of male moving, to right with perhaps spear; red tail and hind leg of dog walking to right; below, four black lines above glazed lower body.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
See also Mommsen, H., Der Affecter. Mainz 1975, 85, no. 4, pl. 20.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 464, no. B791)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0316) (Phase 1)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 96, pl. III, no. 20)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
